elements.text: PART ONE
1: INT. TARDIS CONTROL ROOM.
(FX: TARDIS IS SHUDDERING OUT OF CONTROL. CLOISTER BELL TOLLING.
ENGINES STRAINING AND WARPING. HEX ENTERS BY INTERIOR DOOR. ACE
ALREADY HERE)
Ace! What the hell’s going on?
What makes you think I have any idea?
One minute I’m getting my head down for a kip, the next all the lights have gone out and the whole place is lurching like a bucking bronco, making a noise like a steam engine giving birth.
You’re welcome to look at the controls. See if you can make any sense of them.
Well, those are the warning lights, right? Only I’ve never seen them all lit up at once before.
PAUSE — HEX HEARS CLOISTER BELL
What’s that? Doesn’t sound good.
It’s not. It means the TARDIS is in serious trouble and that the pilot should get to the control room A.S.A.P.
The Doctor? Yeah, where is he?
I don’t know. But if he’s not answering the cloister bell, that can only mean one thing. (BEAT) The Doctor is not in the TARDIS.
OPENING THEME
PROTECT AND SURVIVE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 3
2: INT. TARDIS CONTROL ROOM.
FX: AS BEFORE, WITH CLOISTER BELL SOUNDING. HEX RUNS IN.
Well, he’s not in his room. Or the games room, or the gym, the sauna, the [library] —
FX: BUTTONS ON CONSOLE BLEEP CONFIRMATION
He’s not on board, Hex. Internal scan registers only two life forms in the TARDIS. You and me.
So the Doctor’s done a bunk?
He wouldn’t leave us, not unless he was forced to.
(INCREASINGLY PANICKED) You mean he’s been kidnapped. Great. The Doc’s been kidnapped!
Well, that explains the cloister bell. It’s the TARDIS’s way of letting us know he’s been abducted.
Doesn’t explain why everything else has gone haywire though.
Hex. Panicking isn’t going to help the situation.
No? Well, I’m sorry, Ace, but I can’t think of anything better to do under the circumstances!
If the Doctor’s not on board, then it’s up to us to try to sort things out.
How do you suggest we do that? Play a game of TARDIS console lucky dip until something happens? You press all the red buttons, I’ll press all the green ones?
PROTECT AND SURVIVE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 4
These are the controls that deal with materialization. If I can land the TARDIS, we might be able to get help.
Yeah, good luck with that, landing us somewhere with a TARDIS repair service.
Well, do you have any better ideas?
No. Like I said, ‘panicking’ was kind of my best one.
Well, I’m going to try and materialize, are you going to try and stop me?
No. No, you go for it, doll.
Watch it, mush. (DEEP BREATH) Alright. Here goes. —
(FX: BUTTONS ON CONSOLE BEING PRESSED. TARDIS SOUNDS WORSE, BUT CLOISTER BELL STOPS)
Hey, doesn’t the Doctor normally press that switch first?
FX: BUTTON PRESSED
Hex! He presses that switch last.
No, that’s for take-offs, he presses it first for landings.
Look. If this doesn’t work, you can have a go. But until then, let me get on with it. These buttons here... then that switch there...
FX: TARDIS SHUDDERING AND STRAINING WORSE THAN BEFORE.
PROTECT AND SURVIVE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 5
3: EXT. GARDEN.
(FX: ALBERT IS DIGGING, WHISTLING CABANERA FROM ‘CARMEN’ TO HIMSELF. PEGGY COMES OUT TO GET HIM. BREEZE, BIRDSONG. )
Albert. Cup of tea.
FX: ALBERT TAKES TEA
(STRAIGHTENING UP) Aw, thanks love.
How’s my brave soldier? You’ve dug quite a trench there.
I’ve been at it half the morning. (DRINKS TEA) Hits the spot.
You just be careful, I don’t want you tramping mud all over the carpet.
Don’t worry, I’1ll put some newspaper down first.
And when you’ve done that you can do the windows.
Blimey, Peg, you’re a real slave-driver today.
I know you, Albert Marsden — given half a chance you’1l be in that potting shed of yours with your feet up snoring to the high heavens. You finished with that cup?
FX: APPROACHING AIRCRAFT OVERHEAD
Give me a chance. (FINISHES IT) All done.
FX: AIRCRAFT ROARS OVERHEAD, THEN INTO DISTANCE
That’s the eighth one today.
PROTECT AND SURVIVE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 6
Cup of tea?
No. Aircraft.
Wonder where they’re going. Haven’t seen any coming back.
Hope they don’t. I could do with a bit of peace and quiet.
What about me, out here in the freezing cold? Took me years to get the lawn looking nice, and now look at it.
Well, you just stay away from my herbaceous borders. (BEAT) I tried calling Raymond again.
No answer?
I was hoping to get through to that answering-machine of his, but it just keeps going "bleep bleep” at me.
They did say there might be some trouble with the lines, they want them clear for emergencies.
Isn’t me worrying about my son and daughter-in-law an emergency?
No, love, you know it’s not. Come here.
Oh no, don’t you try hugging me, not with those dirty hands.
They’1l be all right. Our Raymond’s got a good head on his shoulders.
You don’t think he’s already left, to join us up here?
PROTECT AND SURVIVE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page
Not without phoning us first.
But he might not have been able to phone us first.
Well, he’1ll come when he comes.
But what if he never comes?
SUBTLY, THEY’RE NOW TALKING ABOUT THE DOCTOR.
He said he’d come. He promised us.
Only it’s been so long. He should have been here by now.
Then we’ll just have to keep on waiting, won’t we?
I don’t think he is ever coming.
Don’t give up. We can’t give up.
Then what else can we do?
We just have to keep on hoping, that’s all.
FX: IN THE DISTANCE, TARDIS LANDING SOUND BEGINS
What’s that?
It came from down the lane. Wait here, I’1l go and look.
FX: ALBERT MOVES THROUGH SQUEAKING GATE
PROTECT AND SURVIVE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 8
4: INT. TARDIS CONTROL ROOM
FX: FINAL LANDING ‘PLING’ NOISE. TURBULENCE SUBSIDES.
Whoa. We made it.
If you’re going to make a crack about women drivers, I should warn you, I’ve got a baseball bat in my room.
Wasn’t gonna say a word. Though I’ve learned one thing today.
What’s that?
That the TARDIS has a spin cycle.
Very funny.
FX: TARDIS SCANNER OPENS
Well, we’re on Earth, that’s something to be grateful for.
Come on, let’s get some fresh air.
We could always stay put? That cloister gong’s shut up.
Bell. You can stay here if you like, I’m going outside.
FX: TARDIS DOOR OPENS
PROTECT AND SURVIVE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 9
5: EXT. LANE. (CONTINUOUS
FX: TARDIS DOOR OPENS, ACE EMERGES
It’s a bit chilly, you might want to get your coat.
FX: HEX EMERGES
No, it’s all right, I’1ll live. Once you’ve felt the Antarctic
wind in your kecks, you kind of get a different perspective on the whole cold thing.
Suit yourself.
FX: LOCKING TARDIS
We'll try that cottage, it can’t be more than half a mile.
Someone likes to get away from it all. Still, looks twentieth century. Telephone wires but no satellite dish.
Yeah. And I’m guessing this is the guy who lives there.
FX: ALBERT ARRIVES, DISTANT AT FIRST
(CALLING) Hello! Can I help you?
Yeah, maybe you can, we’re a bit... lost.
FX: ALBERT CLOSER
Lost?
Yeah. We’ve kind of gone of holiday by accident.
But you don’t have backpacks, what about your tents?
PROTECT AND SURVIVE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 10
Hex here was being chased by a bull, and threw our stuff at it to distract it.
Hey, I wasn’t the one who was screaming.
I think you’1ll find it was you who was doing the screaming. Like a little girl.
But you don’t have hiking boots. If you don’t mind me saying, you don’t seem to have come out very prepared.
Yeah. Next year we’re doing Skeggy, definite.
You wouldn’t be able to point us in the direction of the nearest town, would you?
You're a bit out of luck, I’m afraid. The nearest is Hebden Bridge and that’s eight miles. If you don’t me asking, what were you doing inside that thing?
What thing?
The police box. I saw you getting out.
FX: HE PATS BOX
Haven’t seen one of these for years. Though shouldn’t it be blue?
I don’t remember ever seeing a white one before.
Ace, I think it’s time we told this good gentleman the truth.
The truth?
PROTECT AND SURVIVE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 11

The thing is I’m due to get married tomorrow, and last night was my stag do. And my hilarious mates, well, as a joke they must have waited until I was out cold and then locked me up in that police box, because the next thing I know I’m waking up inside it with this young lady here.
(EMBARRASSED) Hex!
In my day we just spent the evening playing dominoes.
Yeah, I’m kind of wishing that’s what we’d done too.
So this young lady, she would be — (a)
The innocent victim of a cruel prank. So if you could see your way clear to giving us a lift, we’d be dead grateful.
Well, I don’t know about a lift, but you’re welcome to use the telephone.
Thanks, that would be a great help.
I’m Albert, by the way. Albert Marsden. And you are “Hex”?
Yeah. Short for Hector. Thomas Hector Schofield.
And your friend’s name?
Call me Ace.
Ace?
Yeah. (ASIDE) She wouldn’t tell me her real name either.
PROTECT AND SURVIVE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 12
6: EXT. GARDEN.
FX: ALBERT, ACE AND HEX COMING UP DRIVE, THROUGH GATE
(CALLING) I’m back, dear.
Who is it? Is it —
No, love. It’s a young gentleman, Hex, and his friend Ace.
Why do young people have to have such funny names?
You can hardly talk, love. You wouldn’t have me in the house if I started going around calling you Margaret.
That’s different, everybody’s always called me Peggy. And I don’t like that name, it reminds me of that woman.
Nice to meet you, Peggy.
They were wondering if they might use our telephone.
Well, they’re welcome to try, but I can’t even get through to our Dot now.
They said the phone’s only for emergencies, I hardly think you calling your sister counts.
I suppose whatever these young people need the telephone for is an emergency?
It is, yes, I’m afraid.
Well in that case, follow me.
PROTECT AND SURVIVE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 13
Thank you, you’re very kind.
(FX: ACE AND PEGGY HEAD INDOORS DURING THE ABOVE, CLOSING THE DOOR AFTERWARDS. )
Nice place you’ve got here.
Yes. We’ve been here five years, ever since I retired.
If you don’t mind me asking, though, why are you digging up your lawn? Decided to go for vegetables?
No. It’s to fill the cardboard boxes.
The what?
We’re supposed to pile them up against the walls of our fall-out room. To keep out the radiation.
What did you just say?
PROTECT AND SURVIVE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 14
7: INT. PARLOUR.
FX: PHONE DIALLED
Hello. Is there anyone there? Hello. Hello?
FX: JIGGLES RECEIVER CONTACTS
No luck, dear?
No. I’m not even getting an engaged tone.
Yes, it’s been like that for the last hour. I expect one of the wires has come down. We’re always getting cut off in storms.
Has there been a storm?
No. Odd that. (BEAT) I’m sorry if you can’t phone your friends. Would a cup of tea help?
Yes, that would be lovely, thank you.
FX: DOOR OPENS, HEX ENTERS
Ace, you'll never believe —
Feet! On the newspapers.
sorry.
FX: FEET ON NEWSPAPERS
It’s bad enough with Albert without everyone else tramping dirt
in. I was just making some tea, would you like a cup?
What? Oh, yeah. That would be fantastic.
PROTECT AND SURVIVE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 15
Well I don’t know about ‘fantastic’ but I’11l do my best.
FX: PEGGY DEPARTS INTO KITCHEN, DOOR CLOSES.
Ace, there’s something going on here. Something weird.
You’re telling me. The phone is dead.
Dead? Who were you trying to call, anyway?
UNIT. What do you mean, ‘something weird’?
The old fella out there, he says he’s building a fall-out shelter.
A fall-out shelter?
Yeah. Like in a nuclear war.
PROTECT AND SURVIVE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 16
8: INT. KITCHEN.
(FX: ALL ANNOUNCEMENTS OPEN WITH LOW RUMBLE, LIKE AFTER AN EXPLOSION. THEN ANNOUNCER, THEN THE CLOSING THEME. )
(RADIO)

Your first priority is to make a fall-out room to protect you from radioactive fall-out. This should be the room in your home which is furthest away from the exterior walls and roof. If you have a basement, use that.
(FX: CLOSING THEME — SINISTER MOOG NOTE, SERIES OF SINISTER MOOG BLEEPS, ANOTHER SINISTER MOOG NOTE. )
Here you go, love. You can do your own milk and sugar.
FX: TEA DISTRIBUTED
Peggy. Your husband said he’s building a fall-out shelter.
Oh, that. Waste of time if you ask me. But he says we have to be prepared.
You think there’s going to be a nuclear war?
No, but it doesn’t matter what I think. The government says we have to. They even put a leaflet through our front door.
Can I see this leaflet?
Didn’t you get one? I think Albert had it.
FX: ALBERT ENTERS
What’s that, love?
The leaflet, the one from the government. Have you got it?
PROTECT AND SURVIVE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 17
Here. What’s the matter?
FX: HEX EXAMINES LEAFLET
(READS) “Protect and Survive. What to do to make you and your family as safe as possible in the event of nuclear attack.”
I think I heard about that once in a documentary, it was a thing in the early eighties. But the leaflets were never sent out, I’m sure.
No, dear. We got this one through, when was it?
The day before yesterday.
That’s right. Maybe they haven’t sent them out yet where you live. I’m not surprised, what with all the strikes. Honestly, you’d think the teachers and the — (postmen)
FX: RADIO ANNOUNCEMENT
(RADIO)
Use thick, dense materials to make the walls of your fall-out room thicker to protect against radiation. Use bricks, concrete blocks, timber, or boxes of earth and sand.
FX: RADIO ANNOUNCEMENT ENDS
But why? Why are you building the shelter?
Because it’s our best chance, if the worst comes to the worst. Haven’t you seen the news?
No, I’m afraid I’ve been a bit busy.
Both of you?
PROTECT AND SURVIVE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 18
Yes.
What do you do, by the way?
I’m a nurse, and Ace here, well, she —
I travel. A lot. So tell us. What’s been happening in the news?
We don’t have time to sit around talking all day. I’ve got to tape up the windows, and Albert still has to move the boxes.
Look, how about Ace and I help you out? Might as well make ourselves useful while we’re here.
Well, I suppose an extra pair of hands would come in useful.
Well, then. Boxes is in the garden, lad.
Go on, Hex. You could do with beefing up a bit.
Aw, go bake a cake! (EXITS WITH ALBERT)
Right, then, young lady. Windows it is. Reckon I’ve a spare pinny somewhere.
Pinny?
You don’t want to be getting your clean things mucky.
Alright, whatever. But while we’re about it — you can tell us everything that’s been going on.
PROTECT AND SURVIVE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 19
9: EXT. GARDEN.
All those boxes are to go along the living room wall, same side as the stairs.
Same side as the stairs, got you.
FX: THEY LIFT BOXES
You think there’s really going to be a war?
I don’t know. I think politicians are damn fool enough to do anything. Particularly our lot.
And you think this shelter’s going to make a difference?
That’s what the government are saying. You know what I think, though. I think it’s all just a big bluff.
A bluff?
We’ve got to show the Ruskies that we’re serious and we’re not going to back down. That’s why they’ve sent out the leaflets. To show them we mean business.
PROTECT AND SURVIVE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 20
10: INT. KITCHEN.
I’m trying to think back to how it all started. Here, love, you hold the chair while I get the net curtains.
(FX: FLOOR SCRAPES, CURTAINS BEING TAKEN DOWN DURING THE
You sure you don’t want me to do it?
No, they’re my curtains. And then you can help me put them in the airing cupboard. I don’t want them getting any paint on them.
Paint? What paint?
FX: RADIO ANNOUNCEMENT
(RADIO)

You must also prepare the rest of your house to limit the damage from heat and blast. Remove anything flammable such as net curtains, newspapers and magazines. You should then coat the windows with diluted white paint, to reflect the heat flash.
FX: RADIO ANNOUNCEMENT ENDS. PEGGY FINISHES WITH CURTAINS.
Yes, that was it. It was all something to do with the uprisings they were having in all those Eastern Bloc countries, like Poland and Hungary and Czechoslovakia.
Yes, I remember, there were all the protests for democracy.
Well, the Russian President, he told them all to go home, and when they didn’t, he sent in the tanks.
PROTECT AND SURVIVE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 21
11: INT. LIVING ROOM.
FX: ALBERT TAKES UP THE STORY WHILE PILING BOXES WITH HEX
I remember seeing it on the news. They just opened fire on the demonstrators... even the children.
At the orders of the Soviet President? Gorbachov?

What? No. General Secretary Vladimir Kryuchkov. I remember the name because he sounds like a James Bond villain. And then there were more demonstrations in East Germany, along the Berlin wall, and so the Russians went into West Berlin, to restore order... or so they said.
PROTECT AND SURVIVE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 22
12: INT. KITCHEN.
FX: ACE AND PEGGY WHITEWASHING WINDOWS
But this meant all the American bases in West Berlin were now controlled by the Russians, so the Americans gave the Russians an ultimatum.
PROTECT AND SURVIVE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 23
13: INT. LIVING ROOM.
FX: ALBERT PILES A BOX, THEN PAUSES

And then one of our satellites spots there are Soviet tanks gathering on the border with West Germany, at a town called Helmstedt. For defence, the Soviets say, but by then it’s too late as the Americans have dropped a bomb on it. What they call a battlefield nuclear weapon.
PROTECT AND SURVIVE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 24
14: INT. KITCHEN.
FX: ACE AND PEGGY FINISH PAINTING WINDOWS
That was three days ago. The news has been quiet ever since. I think they’re deciding what to do next.
And it all started with the uprisings... So it’s 1989?
Yes. The ninth of November. Don’t you even know that?
So, what do we do after we’ve whitewashed the windows?
FX: RADIO ANNOUNCEMENT
(RADIO)
Inside your fallout room you should prepare an inner refuge, to give you extra protection during the first two days after the attack, when the danger from radiation is most critical.
PROTECT AND SURVIVE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 25
15: INT. SHELTER.
FX: DOOR CREAKS OPEN, HEX AND ALBERT GO DOWN INTO SHELTER
Careful, watch your step, it’s very steep.
Nice fall-out shelter, mate. Liking it.
Just put the box by the entrance of the inner refuge, but not blocking the way in.
FX: HEX DOES SO
You’re planning on spending two weeks down here?
No. The inner refuge is just for the first two days. For the rest of the two weeks, we’re allowed to use the rest of the room.
Wow, luxury. And then what?
And then they’1l sound the all-clear, and we can come out.
If there’s anything left.
I wouldn’t worry, lad. Nothing’s going to actually happen.
Yeah. Either that or you’re dead no matter what you do, and this is just their way of keeping you busy.
PROTECT AND SURVIVE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 26
16: INT. KITCHEN.
FX: RADIO ANNOUNCEMENT
(RADIO)

You will need to store enough food and water in your fallout room for each member of your family for fourteen days. Choose foods which can be eaten cold and which are tinned or well-wrapped. Don’t forget to make sure you have a tin opener in your inner refuge.
FX: ANNOUNCEMENT ENDS
(FX: PEGGY IS FILLING BOTTLES FROM THE TAP AS ACE SORTS THROUGH CUTLERY DRAWERS )
Tin opener. Tin opener — here!
Any more bottles, love?
No, the only other thing I could find was a watering can.
Hmmm. I suppose it counts as a container.
FX: SHE STARTS FILLING IT
Is all this for you and Albert?
What’s that, dear?
Only the leaflet says three and a half gallons per person, and you must have stored more than twice that.
FX: PEGGY STOPS FILLING CAN
TEARFUL SNIFF
I’m sorry, have I said something wrong?
PROTECT AND SURVIVE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 27
No, dear. It’s.. when you arrived, we were expecting, hoping for someone else to turn up.
Who?

My son Raymond, and his wife Joanna. They said they’d come up to stay with us, but I haven’t heard from them for two days. They live in London, you see. But the radio has been saying that the motorways are for essential services only.
I’m sorry. I’m sure he’s on his way.

That’s very kind of you to say, dear. (BEAT) It’s funny. He’s a grown man now, but when I picture him, I still see a little boy playing cowboys and Indians in the garden. Just underneath that apple tree.
He must have had a wonderful childhood, growing up here.
Couldn’t wait to leave, first chance he got, though.
FX: ALBERT AND HEX ENTER
Inner refuge finished and ready for inspection, ma’am.
You’re not getting me down in that cellar, Albert Marsden. You can carry the water down there yourself.
It’s alright, I’1ll help.
No, lad, you’ve done enough.
And then you can clear all the newspapers from the hall.
Why don’t you let us do that? We can do it on our way out.
PROTECT AND SURVIVE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 28
Are you leaving us, love?
Well, if we’re walking to the next town, we should make a start.
If you’re sure. The newspapers, they go in the garage. Albert bundles them up for the Scouts to do recycling.
Okay. And thanks, for being so kind.
Not at all, dear. It’s been nice having someone to talk to other than the radio.
That radio! It never stops.
Yes. I hope... I hope you don’t have to wait too much longer. Goodbye.
Yeah, cheers.
Goodbye, and good luck.
FX: ACE AND HEX LEAVE
PROTECT AND SURVIVE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 29
17: EXT. GARAGE.
FX: ACE AND HEX ENTER GARAGE THROUGH SIDE DOOR
So why you were so keen to clear away the newspapers?
Isn’t it obvious? To find out what’s been going on.
FX: NEWSPAPERS UNBUNDLED
Three days ago. “Parliament passes emergency powers act. All airports are to be closed. All hospitals are to be cleared of non-critical patients to make room for expected casualties.”

Four days ago. “Following widespread panic-buying of petrol, number ten has announced that remaining supplies are to be restricted to official vehicles. Stocks of tinned food are at a critical level.”
“Anti-war demonstrations in London, Manchester and Liverpool end in riots and looting. Curfews are now imposed in all cities.”
Yesterday. “The Archbishop of Canterbury has appealed for calm and for prayers for peace, as the government places all emergency services on stand-by.”

Today. “The Prime Minister has flown to Paris for a meeting of NATO, but remains “optimistic” of a diplomatic solution. Foreign office sources refuse to confirm reports of a series of nuclear explosions in the Middle East.”
FX: THEY PUT DOWN NEWSPAPERS
But none of this ever happened.
No. Something’s wrong.
Maybe, I don’t know, we’re in a parallel universe?
PROTECT AND SURVIVE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 30
Or something has changed the course of history. Bringing the world to the brink of nuclear war.
But it’s not going to happen, is it? No-one would ever really push the button, would they?
FX: PLANE ROARS OVERHEAD
I hope you’re right, Hex. Because whatever’s going on, we’re
stuck here for the foreseeable future.
No. No, there’s still a way out. The TARDIS.
PROTECT AND SURVIVE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 31
18: INT. KITCHEN.
Have they gone, dear?
They’re just off down the lane. Pity. I liked them.
Don’t worry, love. They’1ll be back, soon enough. It’s not as if there’s anywhere else they can go.
FX: RADIO ANNOUNCEMENT
(RADIO) If an attack with nuclear weapons is expected, you will hear the following sound.
FX: RISING AND FALLING SIREN
(RADIO)

If you are at home when you hear this sound, turn off the gas and electricity at the mains, and go to your fallout room. If you are not at home, but can get there within two minutes, do so. Otherwise take cover at your place of work. If you are in the open, take cover in the nearest building. If you cannot reach a building, lie flat on the ground and cover your head and your hands.
PROTECT AND SURVIVE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 32
19: EXT. LANE.
FX: ANOTHER PLANE ROARS OVERHEAD. ACE AND HEX RUNNING
Come on, it should be just around the next corner.
FX: THEY SLOW DOWN
It’s gone. The TARDIS has gone.
It must have dematerialized. Without us.
But it can’t have.
Yeah. Unless.
Unless what?
Unless the Doctor was still in it.
The Doctor wouldn’t abandon us. (BEAT) We can’t hang around here. We have to make contact with UNIT somehow.
What do you suggest? We walk to the next town?
Walk? Don’t you know how to drive?
PROTECT AND SURVIVE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 33
20: INT. GARAGE.
FX: GARAGE MAIN DOOR RATTLES OPEN
You’re not going to nick Albert’s car?
Borrow, that’s all.
You can’t hotwire a Morris Minor, it’s practically vintage!
FX: KEYS JANGLE
I don’t have to.
Hey, where d’you get those?
(FX: OPENING CAR DOOR) Toby jug on the sideboard. I thought, just in case... (BEAT) Oh, get in, will you?
(GETTING IN) Look, I’m not sure about this. —
(FROM DOORWAY, OFF) Glad to hear it, lad.
Rumbled. (ALOUD) Albert. Sorry about this, but we don’t have any choice. We’ll make sure you get it back.
(FX: SCRAPING ON CONCRETE AS HE HEFTS SPADE LIKE A WEAPON) No, young lady. You’1ll give it back, right now.
Albert, mate. Put the spade down, eh?
(JABBING SPADE) Go on, get out of it!
You keep on swinging that thing about, you’1ll ruin your paintwork!
PROTECT AND SURVIVE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 34
I’1l paintwork you, [young lady]
FX: AIR ATTACK WARNING SOUNDS IN DISTANCE
What’s that?
Oh no.
That’s the air attack warning. (FX: DROPS SPADE) Oh my. The air attack warning!
Then it’s really happening?
(SHAKING HER) Ace. Ace! They’ve only gone and started World War Three!
PROTECT AND SURVIVE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 35
21: INT. HALLWAY.
(RADIO, FROM KITCHEN)
Air attack warning. Go to your fall-out room or take shelter. Do not panic. Stay calm. This is not a test. Repeat. (MESSAGE REPEATS IN B/G THROUGH: )
FX: DOOR OPENS
Albert, we have to close all the doors! The windows, too —
(STOPS, SURPRISED) Oh!
